qas.question: The adaptive immune system must distinguish between what types of molecules?
What molecules are parts of the body of an organism in immunology?
What molecules are recognized as foreign by the immune system?
What term is shorthand for antibody generators?
Antigens bind to what in order to elicit a response of the immune system?
What does not depend on the immune system's ability to distinguish between the self and others?
What is a one class of self molecule?
What can not be distinguished from foreign substances by the immune system?
What do self molecules bind to?
What happens when an antigen fails to bind to an immune receptor?

context: Both innate and <b5_0>adaptive immunity<b5_0/> depend on the ability of the immune system to distinguish between <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2>self and non-self<a0_1/><a0_0/> molecules<a0_2/>. In immunology, <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><b7_0>self<a1_1/> molecules<b7_0/><a1_2/><a1_0/> are those components of an organism's body that can be distinguished from foreign substances by the immune system. Conversely, <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2>non-self<a2_1/> molecules<a2_2/><a2_0/> are those recognized as foreign molecules. One class of non-self molecules are called <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><b6_0>antigens<b6_0/><a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/> (short for antibody generators) and are defined as substances that bind to <a4_0><a4_2>specific <b8_0>immune <a4_1>receptors<b8_0/><a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/> and elicit an <b9_0>immune response<b9_0/>.
